author: Grimms
text: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside.

author: Grimms
text: The fisherman used to go out all day long a-fishing; and one day, as he sat on the shore with his rod, looking at the sparkling waves and watching his line, all on a sudden his float was dragged away deep into the water: and in drawing it up he pulled out a great fish.

author: Grimms
text: But the fish said, "Pray let me live!

author: Grimms
text: I am not a real fish; I am an enchanted prince: put me in the water again, and let me go!"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, ho!" said the man, "you need not make so many words about the matter; I will have nothing to do with a fish that can talk: so swim away, sir, as soon as you please!"

author: Grimms
text: Then he put him back into the water, and the fish darted straight down to the bottom, and left a long streak of blood behind him on the wave.

author: Grimms
text: When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again.

author: Grimms
text: "Did not you ask it for anything?" said the wife, "we live very wretchedly here, in this nasty dirty pigsty; do go back and tell the fish we want a snug little cottage."

author: Grimms
text: The fisherman did not much like the business: however, he went to the seashore; and when he came back there the water looked all yellow and green.

author: Grimms
text: And he stood at the water"s edge, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the fish came swimming to him, and said, "Well, what is her will?

author: Grimms
text: What does your wife want?"

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the fisherman, "she says that when I had caught you, I ought to have asked you for something before I let you go; she does not like living any longer in the pigsty, and wants a snug little cottage."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home, then," said the fish; "she is in the cottage already!"

author: Grimms
text: So the man went home, and saw his wife standing at the door of a nice trim little cottage.

author: Grimms
text: "Come in, come in!" said she; "is not this much better than the filthy pigsty we had?"

author: Grimms
text: And there was a parlour, and a bedchamber, and a kitchen; and behind the cottage there was a little garden, planted with all sorts of flowers and fruits; and there was a courtyard behind, full of ducks and chickens.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the fisherman, "how happily we shall live now!"

author: Grimms
text: "We will try to do so, at least," said his wife.

author: Grimms
text: Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, "Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle."

author: Grimms
text: "Wife," said the fisherman, "I don"t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in."

author: Grimms
text: "Nonsense!" said the wife; "he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!"

author: Grimms
text: The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: "Well, what does she want now?" said the fish.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the man, dolefully, "my wife wants to live in a stone castle."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home, then," said the fish; "she is standing at the gate of it already."

author: Grimms
text: So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle.

author: Grimms
text: "See," said she, "is not this grand?"

author: Grimms
text: With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses.

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said the man, "now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives."

author: Grimms
text: "Perhaps we may," said the wife; "but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that."

author: Grimms
text: So they went to bed.

author: Grimms
text: The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, "Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land."

author: Grimms
text: "Wife, wife," said the man, "why should we wish to be the king?

author: Grimms
text: I will not be king."

author: Grimms
text: "Then I will," said she.

author: Grimms
text: "But, wife," said the fisherman, "how can you be king--the fish cannot make you a king?"

author: Grimms
text: "Husband," said she, "say no more about it, but go and try!

author: Grimms
text: I will be king."

author: Grimms
text: So the man went away quite sorrowful to think that his wife should want to be king.

author: Grimms
text: This time the sea looked a dark grey colour, and was overspread with curling waves and the ridges of foam as he cried out:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: "Well, what would she have now?" said the fish.

author: Grimms
text: "Alas!" said the poor man, "my wife wants to be king."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home," said the fish; "she is king already."

author: Grimms
text: Then the fisherman went home; and as he came close to the palace he saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets.

author: Grimms
text: And when he went in he saw his wife sitting on a throne of gold and diamonds, with a golden crown upon her head; and on each side of her stood six fair maidens, each a head taller than the other.

author: Grimms
text: "Well, wife," said the fisherman, "are you king?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said she, "I am king."

author: Grimms
text: And when he had looked at her for a long time, he said, "Ah, wife! what a fine thing it is to be king!

author: Grimms
text: Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as long as we live."

author: Grimms
text: "I don"t know how that may be," said she; "never is a long time.

author: Grimms
text: I am king, it is true; but I begin to be tired of that, and I think I should like to be emperor."

author: Grimms
text: "Alas, wife! why should you wish to be emperor?" said the fisherman.

author: Grimms
text: "Husband," said she, "go to the fish!

author: Grimms
text: I say I will be emperor."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, wife!" replied the fisherman, "the fish cannot make an emperor, I am sure, and I should not like to ask him for such a thing."

author: Grimms
text: "I am king," said Ilsabill, "and you are my slave; so go at once!"

author: Grimms
text: So the fisherman was forced to go; and he muttered as he went along, "This will come to no good, it is too much to ask; the fish will be tired at last, and then we shall be sorry for what we have done."

author: Grimms
text: He soon came to the seashore; and the water was quite black and muddy, and a mighty whirlwind blew over the waves and rolled them about, but he went as near as he could to the water"s brink, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: "What would she have now?" said the fish.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the fisherman, "she wants to be emperor."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home," said the fish; "she is emperor already."

author: Grimms
text: So he went home again; and as he came near he saw his wife Ilsabill sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on her head full two yards high; and on each side of her stood her guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than my finger.

author: Grimms
text: And before her stood princes, and dukes, and earls: and the fisherman went up to her and said, "Wife, are you emperor?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said she, "I am emperor."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the man, as he gazed upon her, "what a fine thing it is to be emperor!"

author: Grimms
text: "Husband," said she, "why should we stop at being emperor?

author: Grimms
text: I will be pope next."

author: Grimms
text: "O wife, wife!" said he, "how can you be pope? there is but one pope at a time in Christendom."

author: Grimms
text: "Husband," said she, "I will be pope this very day."

author: Grimms
text: "But," replied the husband, "the fish cannot make you pope."

author: Grimms
text: "What nonsense!" said she; "if he can make an emperor, he can make a pope: go and try him."

author: Grimms
text: So the fisherman went.

author: Grimms
text: But when he came to the shore the wind was raging and the sea was tossed up and down in boiling waves, and the ships were in trouble, and rolled fearfully upon the tops of the billows.

author: Grimms
text: In the middle of the heavens there was a little piece of blue sky, but towards the south all was red, as if a dreadful storm was rising.

author: Grimms
text: At this sight the fisherman was dreadfully frightened, and he trembled so that his knees knocked together: but still he went down near to the shore, and said:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: "What does she want now?" said the fish.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the fisherman, "my wife wants to be pope."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home," said the fish; "she is pope already."

author: Grimms
text: Then the fisherman went home, and found Ilsabill sitting on a throne that was two miles high.

author: Grimms
text: And she had three great crowns on her head, and around her stood all the pomp and power of the Church.

author: Grimms
text: And on each side of her were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight.

author: Grimms
text: "Wife," said the fisherman, as he looked at all this greatness, "are you pope?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said she, "I am pope."

author: Grimms
text: "Well, wife," replied he, "it is a grand thing to be pope; and now you must be easy, for you can be nothing greater."

author: Grimms
text: "I will think about that," said the wife.

author: Grimms
text: Then they went to bed: but Dame Ilsabill could not sleep all night for thinking what she should be next.

author: Grimms
text: At last, as she was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose.

author: Grimms
text: "Ha!" thought she, as she woke up and looked at it through the window, "after all I cannot prevent the sun rising."

author: Grimms
text: At this thought she was very angry, and wakened her husband, and said, "Husband, go to the fish and tell him I must be lord of the sun and moon."

author: Grimms
text: The fisherman was half asleep, but the thought frightened him so much that he started and fell out of bed.

author: Grimms
text: "Alas, wife!" said he, "cannot you be easy with being pope?"

author: Grimms
text: "No," said she, "I am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without my leave.

author: Grimms
text: Go to the fish at once!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the man went shivering with fear; and as he was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook.

author: Grimms
text: And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon their heads.

author: Grimms
text: And the fisherman crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as he could:

author: Grimms
text: "O man of the sea!

author: Grimms
text: Hearken to me!

author: Grimms
text: My wife Ilsabill Will have her own will, And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!"

author: Grimms
text: "What does she want now?" said the fish.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said he, "she wants to be lord of the sun and moon."

author: Grimms
text: "Go home," said the fish, "to your pigsty again."

author: Grimms
text: And there they live to this very day.
